body:
There's no built-in batch mode but you can use the Python API or a scripting language of your choice to create one. Here's a simple example (save as `batch_sync.py`)
```python
"""
Batch synchronize all video files in a folder. Usage:

    python batch_sync.py /path/to/folder
    
"""
import autosubsync
import glob
import os
import sys

target_folder = sys.argv[1]
# change this for other extensions than .mp4
VIDEO_EXT = 'mp4'

for video_file in glob.glob(os.path.join(target_folder, '*.' + VIDEO_EXT)):
    base = video_file.rpartition('.')[0]
    srt_file = base + '.srt'
    synced_srt_file = base + '_synced.srt'
    print('syncing ' + video_file)
    autosubsync.synchronize(video_file, srt_file, synced_srt_file)
```

Hi, thank you for the quick reply and for this great tool.

I'm not a programmer, so I don't have some skills. I did as you said, I've saved the script as batch_sync.py, and first I just changed the video format, I used mkv. When I ran the script in the same folder with all files I got this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "batch_sync.py", line 12, in <module>
    target_folder = sys.argv[1]
IndexError: list index out of range
```

So I thought could be the line "python batch_sync.py /path/to/folder", so I replaced the `"/path/to/folder"` to the path of the videos and subs, When I run this way, I got a new message error: 

```
File "batch_sync.py", line 6
    """
SyntaxError: (unicode error) 'unicodeescape' codec can't decode bytes in position 84-85: malformed \N character escape
```
Am I doing something wrong? Sorry if this is a dumb question, I have little knowledge of programming.

Edit. I'm on windows 10, if this is important

Both things, `mp4` -> `mkv` & replacing the placeholder `/path/to/folder`, are correct, but I guess you may have hit the (stupid) problem of Windows, Unix and Mac using different types of newline characters so you should have used a different text editor, e.g., Atom or Notepad++ to edit the file.

(To check if this was the case, just try again with this version which already has `mkv`):

```python
"""
Batch synchronize all video files in a folder. Usage:

    python batch_sync.py /path/to/folder
    
"""
import autosubsync
import glob
import os
import sys

target_folder = sys.argv[1]
# change this for other extensions than .mp4
VIDEO_EXT = 'mkv'

for video_file in glob.glob(os.path.join(target_folder, '*.' + VIDEO_EXT)):
    base = video_file.rpartition('.')[0]
    srt_file = base + '.srt'
    synced_srt_file = base + '_synced.srt'
    print('syncing ' + video_file)
    autosubsync.synchronize(video_file, srt_file, synced_srt_file)
```

Ok. Strange Windows-specific issue. Try this:
```python
"""
Batch synchronize all video files in a folder. Usage:

    python batch_sync.py /path/to/folder

"""
import autosubsync
import glob
import os
import sys

if __name__ == '__main__':
    target_folder = sys.argv[1]
    # change this for other extensions than .mp4
    VIDEO_EXT = 'mkv'

    for video_file in glob.glob(os.path.join(target_folder, '*.' + VIDEO_EXT)):
        base = video_file.rpartition('.')[0]
        srt_file = base + '.srt'
        synced_srt_file = base + '_synced.srt'
        print('syncing ' + video_file)
        autosubsync.synchronize(video_file, srt_file, synced_srt_file)
```

Thank you! Now worked very well. 
Thank you so much for your help. Success in your career!
